text: Facial recognition technology (FRT) stands out among various artificial intelligence (AI)-driven tools employed amid the COVID-19 pandemic to mitigate the virus's spread. As strategies for handling future pandemics are being devised, this technology emerges as a potent asset for tracking infected individuals and gathering real-time surveillance data. When employed judiciously, FRT can bolster governmental efforts in executing public health surveillance, a concept described in academic literature as ‘the methodical gathering, storage, utilization, and dissemination of personal data to identify outbreaks and curb disease transmission’. However, FRT brings forth ethical and legal quandaries, including its deployment sans ensuring consent from individuals under surveillance, safeguarding the biometric data amassed through surveillance, and the potential misuse of this information for purposes beyond public health endeavors. Despite its widespread adoption in nations like Russia and China, both during the pandemic and beyond, western jurisdictions exhibit significant reluctance towards its adoption.
